div1.head: Report from Valery Havard to the Adjutant General, July 20, 1900
div1.opener:
File under Elecrozone (Havard)
L.S.306.
HEADQUARTERS
DIVISION OF CUBA
OFFICE OF CHIEF SURGEON.
HAVANA.
July 20th.,1900.
The Adjutant General,
Division of Cuba.
Sir:
div1.p:
Referring to the Electrozone plant in operation in this
city, I have the honor to submit the following remarks:-

During the month of May, 743,000 gallons of this fluid was
manufactured, or at about the rate of 24,000 gallons per day. The
strength in available chlorine, its active principle, averaged
130 grains per gallon. The cost per gallon was $0.00285, amount-
ing to $68.40 per day and to $2052.00 per month.

After consulting with Surgeon Walter Reed, bacteriologist,
W.C. Gorgas, Chief Sanitary Officer and Major W.M. Black, Chief
Engineer, I find that electrozone of this strength (130 grains of
chlorine per gallon) is not only a deodorant, but a valuable dis-
infectant and germicide, and that its cost of production is at
least one half less than that of an equivalent amount of chlo-
rine obtained from chloride of lime, and about two hundred times
less than a solution of bichloride of mercury of equal disinfect-
ing efficiency.

I therefore recommend that this electrozone plant be kept
in operation and the disinfectant used as heretofore, and for the
various purposes to which it has been applied. It seems also
best that the same quantity be produced, that is about 24000 gal-
lons per day. Whether this amount can be considerably reduced
later, will depend on the extent of digging and excavation made
necessary by the repaving of streets and laying of pipes and sew
ers.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully yours, V. Havard Major & Surgeon, U.S.A.
Chief Surgeon.
